Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Teaching Metacognition: Helping engineering students take ownership of their own learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a three-phase design-based research project for strengthening undergraduate engineering students' metacognitive skills. It begins with prototype development and testing of 6 to 8 intervention modules, then transitions to refinement and improved development of these based on a variety of assessments, and ends with the preparation of materials for instructor professional development. Metacognition is often referred to as "thinking about thinking" because it relies on individual reflection and self-awareness. Learning science has found metacognition skill to be important precursor to becoming an effective independent learner and problem-solver. It is the foundation of becoming a lifelong learner. In order to deliberately cultivate metacognitive skills, this project has provided a structured definition that will facilitate this study of the impact of integrating metacognition into specific formal learning activities in engineering.

The first phase focuses on the development and pilot implementation of a coordinated set of intervention modules intended to strengthen the metacognitive skills of students in a sophomore engineering course at a small undergraduate engineering school. Included in the first phase is the assessment of impact on each student's metacognitive development. Each intervention module consists of a training video on metacognitive knowledge and awareness, a contextualized classroom content module, and a modified standard assignment to provide students with opportunities to practice metacognitive regulation. The assessment effort is focused on developing indicators (rubrics and metrics) that engineering instructors can use to measure student progress in developing metacognitive skill.

In the second phase, the research outcomes from Phase 1 are used to revise the set of interventions for the testbed sophomore course and, additionally, prepare similar interventions for a second engineering education classroom context - a freshman course at a large comprehensive state land-grant university. The goal of the revisions is to improve the interventions and to focus on the transferability of both the interventions and the indicators to other lower division courses. The research aspect of Phase 2 refines the Phase 1 research questions and adds a focus on understanding what elements of an intervention and context are most important to consider when considering transferability to other courses and instructors. Finally, Phase 3 will focus on training faculty instructors, in order to boost the initial dissemination of intervention materials. The project will develop recommendations for instructors on how to further translate the set of interventions for use in their own classroom contexts. The PI team plans to develop and conduct training for instructors at both institutions. Open access to salient findings, tools, and guides will be provided through an online repository that is also linked through CLEERHub.org, a collaborative engineering education research site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metacognition , defined as the knowledge and regulation of one's own cognitive (or thinking) processes, is critically important to student learning and particularly instrumental in engineering problem-solving. The purpose of this project was to generate transferable tools to teach and evaluate undergraduate engineering students' metacognitive skills. To accomplish this, we completed a three-phased project in which we first used research methods to test 1) an intervention designed to facilitate development of student's metacognitive skills and 2) associated indicators, i.e., assessment tools instructors can use evaluate student's progress with regard to developing metacognitive skills. In the second phase, we used the research outcomes from Phase 1 and interviews with instructors to revise the intervention and indictor tools for differing engineering education contexts.  Phase 3 focused on dissemination of intervention materials and indicator tools, including recommendations for instructors on how to further translate our intervention for use in their own classroom contexts.  

The intellectual merit of the project includes three primary outcomes: the intervention, the indicator rubric, and a framework for giving feedback.   The intervention consists of a series of training videos on metacognitive knowledge and awareness, contextualized classroom modules, and metacognitive assignment modifications to provide opportunities to practice metacognitive regulation.  The metacognitive indicator rubric is designed to assist instructors in evaluating students' responses to questions about their learning processes and giving feedback. The first dimension of the rubric focuses on identifying strategies cited in student responses. The second dimension of the rubric focuses on evaluating the evidence students cite to support the use of specific strategies. Evidence is evaluated based on how concrete, demonstrable, and objective it is.

In conjunction with the metacognitive indicator rubric, we developed the A-ACE framework to help instructors generate constructive and supportive formative feedback to students. A-ACE stands for Acknowleging, Affirming, Challenging, and Encouraging. Acknowledging means recognizing our limited understanding of our students and believing the best about them and helps set a positive attitude that undergirds the Affirming, Challenging, and Encouraging elements of our feedback. Acknowledging our limited understanding of our students and their situation helps us to believe the best about them and seeks to support their growth and accurate self-awareness. Acknowledging avoids making assumptions about our students. Further, in order to help our students grow we must first believe they can.  Affirming is giving sincere praise for positive behavior, however small. For example, praising honest effort even if an ineffective strategy is used. Challenging involves gently prompting students towards accurate self-assessment through questions. For example, a student with good grades can be challenged to examine their learning by asking if they are able to apply the concepts to real problems or situations. Finally, encouraging is authentically letting students know you believe that they are capable of improving - with effort and perseverance - and may include offering suggestions to try. Such encouragement supports a growth mindset. 

This project has had broad impacts by engaging engineering undergraduate students, graduate students, instructors, and researchers through targeted, interactive experiences and through national reach.  Undergraduate students participated in the interventions.  Graduate students served as participants in interventions but also as researchers on the project.  Instructors within and outside of engineering have served as study participants and as partners in the development of teaching interventions to incite metacognitive change.  In the past two years, we have given 5 workshops, 1 webinar, and 4 presentations on various aspects of implementing the metacognition intervention. One of the workshops was a two-part virtual intervention with graduate students. The webinar was a two-part experience for educators and had national and international reach. Our intervention modules have been used by people at at least ten institutions (including our 2 home institutions).  We have also supported the dissemination of our work through our website, skillful-learning.org, our Skillful Learning YouTube channel (videos with closed captions), and our skillful.learning@gmail.com Google account.
